DataElement.preferredName: Nasal Cavity and Paranasal Sinus Squamous Cell Carcinoma Disease Involvement Anatomic Site
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A response used to determine the locations within the body of an abnormal condition connected to a rare, keratinizing or non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma arising from the mucosal epithelium of the nasal cavity or the paranasal sinuses.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Nasal Cavity and Paranasal Sinus Squamous Cell Carcinoma Disease or Disorder Involvement
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A rare, keratinizing or non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma arising from the mucosal epithelium of the nasal cavity or the paranasal sinuses.  It affects most often the maxillary sinus.  Less frequently, it arises from the nasal cavity, ethmoid sinus, sphenoid sinus, and frontal sinus.  Symptoms include nasal fullness, epistaxis, rhinorhea, pain, and paresthesia.  Patients with nasal squamous cell carcinoma usually present earlier than patients with maxillary sinus carcinoma and have a better prognosis compared to the latter group._Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function._To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Nasal Cavity and Paranasal Sinus Squamous Cell Carcinoma
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A rare, keratinizing or non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma arising from the mucosal epithelium of the nasal cavity or the paranasal sinuses.  It affects most often the maxillary sinus.  Less frequently, it arises from the nasal cavity, ethmoid sinus, sphenoid sinus, and frontal sinus.  Symptoms include nasal fullness, epistaxis, rhinorhea, pain, and paresthesia.  Patients with nasal squamous cell carcinoma usually present earlier than patients with maxillary sinus carcinoma and have a better prognosis compared to the latter group.

Concepts.definition: A rare, keratinizing or non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma arising from the mucosal epithelium of the nasal cavity or the paranasal sinuses.  It affects most often the maxillary sinus.  Less frequently, it arises from the nasal cavity, ethmoid sinus, sphenoid sinus, and frontal sinus.  Symptoms include nasal fullness, epistaxis, rhinorhea, pain, and paresthesia.  Patients with nasal squamous cell carcinoma usually present earlier than patients with maxillary sinus carcinoma and have a better prognosis compared to the latter group.

Property.preferredDefinition: Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.:To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.

Concepts.definition: Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.
To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Named locations of or within the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One and the other; relating to or being two in conjunction.: To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.

Concepts.definition: One and the other; relating to or being two in conjunction.
To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The inferior region of the skull consisting of an internal (cerebral), and an external (basilar) surface.: Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else.

Concepts.definition: The portion of the skull that forms the floor on which the brain lies. The internal surface of the cranial base has three large depressions that lie on different levels known as the anterior, middle, and posterior cranial fossae.
Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The bony cavity of the skull which contains the eye, anterior portion of the optic nerve, ocular muscles and ocular adnexa. Seven bones contribute to the structure of the orbit: the frontal, maxillary, zygomatic, sphenoid, lacrimal, ethmoid, and palatine bones.: Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else.

Concepts.definition: The bony cavity of the skull which contains the eye, anterior portion of the optic nerve, ocular muscles and ocular adnexa. Seven bones contribute to the structure of the orbit: the frontal, maxillary, zygomatic, sphenoid, lacrimal, ethmoid, and palatine bones.
Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else.
